Graphical abstract An effects of the hierarchical pore structures or pore type on guard bed catalyst during heavy oil hydroprocessing. The hydrodemetallization (HDM) activity and the stability of FeMo supported catalysts have been investigated during the hydroprocessing of heavy crude oil. The prototype FeMo catalysts were developed in this study as guard-bed catalysts. Such type of front catalyst is frequently used in complex hydrotreatment to protect the more vulnerable subsequent catalysts. Various prototype supports were synthesized in this study to produce different textural properties. Such textural properties were generated and optimized by using different support compositions (0−75 wt.% activated carbon in alumina) and following a certain support pretreatment methodology for pore expansion. Both the support composition and the pretreatment methodology have significantly contributed in developing an optimized HDM catalyst with a large pore volume and a distinctive bimodal pore structure. The large pore volume substantially improved the metal retention capacity, while the bimodal pore structure remarkably reduced the diffusion limitation, allowing the large hydrocarbon molecules (i.e., asphaltene) to reach the inner catalytic sites to enhance their conversion rates. The presence of carbon in the catalyst support, even after calcination, considerably reduced coke and metal depositions on pore-mouths and catalytic sites. The textural and the mechanical properties of support indicate that the optimum composition is attained when the carbon-alumina ratio is 1:1 (50/50 wt.%). The role of textual properties on catalyst stability was investigated by comparing fresh and spent catalysts. The characterization of spent catalysts indicates that the bimodal type of pore has stable performance with time-on-stream (TOS). Keywords Residue HDM Asphaltene Metals deposition Deactivation Textural properties 1 Introduction The global trend in fossil fuel indicates that heavy oil production is continuously increasing and is expected to further increase in the near future to fulfill the world demand for energy. Such high demand can be attributed to the fact that 80 % of global energy supply still relies on fossil fuel and the evident shortage in light crude supplies due to reservoir depletion. The refining options for heavy oils are limited since such feedstock has large amounts of complex hydrocarbon molecules (i.e., asphaltene) and high metal contents, which ultimately cause irreversible deactivation for hydrotreating catalysts [1]. Considering the global demand for clean fossil fuels, many modern refineries are currently adopting hydrotreating (HDT) technologies to enhance the quality of their final product. The process of Atmospheric Residue De-Sulfurization (ARDS) is one of the most mature technologies to refine heavy petroleum feedstock, where the impurities can be extracted by selectively reacting them with hydrogen in catalyst beds at elevated temperature and pressure. A number of reactions take place in this hydrotreating process, which includes hydrodemetallization (HDM), hydrodesulfurization (HDS), hydrodenitrogenation (HDN), and hydrodeasphaltenes (HDAsph) conversion through hydrocracking. The complexity of these reactions profoundly depends on the selection of the catalyst system and the designated operating conditions. Although heavy oil hydrotreatment is widely considered as a well investigated topic in literature [2–5], limited information has been reported about the impact of support’s textural properties on the catalyst’s stability and deactivation behavior [6,7]. Residue hydroprocessing is known for its relatively high operational and capital expenses. However, such high processing costs are typically compensated by the quality of products. The high operating cost is mainly attributed to the severe operating conditions (i.e., temperature and pressure), the hydrogen consumption, and the utilization of complex system of catalysts. The process typically operates with 3 or 4 reactors. The first reactor is known as the guard-bed, which is generally loaded with HDM catalyst to remove most of the metals from the feedstock in order to protect the subsequent more vulnerable HDS and HDN catalysts. The second reactor, on the other hand, has the HDS catalyst for sulfur removal. The third reactor contains both HDS and HDN catalysts to remove the remaining sulfur and nitrogen heteroatoms. The last reactor (i.e., the 4th reactor), on the other hand, has the mild hydrocracking (HCR) catalyst to enhance the conversion rate [8]. The feasibility of heavy feedstock hydrotreatment can be enhanced by extending the duration of the run. One of the key elements for ensuring satisfactory run duration is the utilization of an efficient HDM catalyst in the guard-bed reactor. The efficiency of the HDM catalyst is based on two parameters: the high HDM activity and the large metal retention capacity. Previous studies [6,9] indicated that the deactivation in HDM catalyst is typically divided into three distinct phases. The first phase illustrates a rapid initial deactivation that is attributed to coke deposition on acidic sites and micropores. This is followed by a slower and more consistent deactivation phase that is mainly influenced by the gradual metal deposition on the catalyst surface [10–12]. The last phase of deactivation is characterized by another rapid deactivation that is mainly caused by pore mouth plugging (i.e., diffusion limitation). Previous studies [10–15] also suggested that a satisfactory run duration of HDM catalysts can be achieved by modifying the textural properties of the catalyst to enhance the HDM activity and ensure a large mental retention capacity. The HDM reaction is considered a primary process in hydrotreatment through which the metals (i.e., Ni and V) are removed, and the large hydrocarbon molecules (i.e., asphaltenes) are disaggregated. The HDM reaction is frequently associated with the guard-bed catalyst, which is designated to remove and trap metals in solid metal sulfide forms. The depositions of vanadium and nickel sulfides within catalyst are expected to increase with time-on-stream (TOS); therefore, the reaction conditions should be efficiently adjusted for the catalyst to continue its respective functions (organometallic decomposition) and prolong its life cycle [16]. Heterogeneous catalysis plays a major role in emerging sustainable fuel processing technologies for the refining industry. To enhance textural properties of heterogeneous catalysts, different materials have been utilized in their support preparations, including inorganic solid (mixed oxides), sol-gel materials, polymers, and carbon [17–20]. For heavy oil hydrotreatment, the efforts have been directed toward the utilization of carbon in alumina support [21–23]. Lopez-Salinas et al. [21] reported that the mixing amorphous carbon black with alumina can generate a very promising support for H-Oil catalysts. . Lopez-Salinas and coworkers also reported that the presence of carbon in NiMo supported catalyst relatively promoted the HDS and HDN activities, along with the heavy metal removal due to macro-pores formation. Such enhancement in catalytic hydrotreating activities for alumina-carbon supported catalysts was also reported [22]. Maity et al. [23], on the other hand, reported a notable enhancement in the catalytic stability for carbon supported HDM catalyst due to high metal retention capacity. This study aims to illustrate how the performance of the HDM catalyst can be enhanced by developing a catalyst with large pore diameter and large pore volume, and to exemplify how these textural properties hinder the catalyst deactivation rate in the hydroprocessing of heavy petroleum feedstock. The textural properties were optimized by utilizing an optimal amount of activated carbon in the support, and by following a certain preparation methodology. The role of textual properties on catalyst stability was investigated by studying and comparing the properties of fresh and spent catalysts. The results clearly indicate that utilizing certain percentage of activated carbon significantly enhanced the pore size distribution and the total pore volume, which respectively enhanced the diffusion of large hydrocarbon molecules and the metal retention capacity. The observed enhancement in catalyst stability is also attributed to the selective deposition of coke and metals on the bare surface rather than on the pore-mouth. 2 Experiment The textural and the mechanical properties of supported catalysts play a key role in their hydrotreating performance. In this study, both alumina and carbon were utilized in the support synthesis. The Versal pseudo-boehmite (Honeywell UOP’s Versal™) alumina and activated carbon (Sigma-Aldrich) were obtained from a commercial supplier in the form of powder with high-purity and low bulk density. 2.1 Preparation of supports and textural properties This study mainly focuses on the catalyst textural properties, which is an innate property of the support. The preparation methodology and the support composition are the two critical parameters considered in this study to obtain the desired textural properties. Around 300 g of supports were prepared by physically mixing Versal pseudo-boehmite, polyethylene glycol (PEG 4000), and activated carbon, which are peptized in around 170 mL peptizing agent with an optimized concentration of acid (i.e., deionized water with 5 vol% nitric acid) [13]. The exact volume of peptizing solution was slightly varied with support composition (i.e., alumina/carbon ratio). Different amounts of carbon in alumina were used in the support preparation. The carbon fractions in alumina were 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and 75 wt. %, which resulted in six supported catalysts respectively labeled as HDM-4, HDM-5, HDM-6, HDM-7, HDM-3, and HDM-8. The boehmite and carbon mixture was first mixed as a dry powder, and then the mixture was gradually added to the necessary amount of deionized water to obtain a dough, which was extruded in a mechanical extruder (Fuji Paudal MG 55-1 Extruder and Kneader, RI USA) at a constant speed. The extrudates were kept at room temperature and then dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried supports were calcined at 550 °C for 4 h, at a heating rate of 2.5 °C/min in a rotating quartz tube furnace (HTR 11/150, Carbolite, German). 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The supported catalysts were prepared using various support compositions of carbon and alumina. The incipient wetness co-impregnation method was used to impregnate the supports with the active metal (i.e., Mo) and the promotor (i.e., Fe), using the appropriate amounts of ammonium heptamolybdate (Sigma Aldrich, 99.98 %) and ferric nitrate (Sigma Aldrich, 99.999 %). The co-impregnation solution was adjusted with aqueous ammonia to obtain monomeric species of Mo and Fe(MoO42 −−). The impregnated supports were air-dried at room temperature for 12 h, then oven-dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the catalysts were calcined in the presence of inert gas at 450 °C for 4 h. The chemical composition of supports and supported catalysts were determined by using inductive couple argon plasma (ICAP) spectroscopy (Model: ICP-AES Liberty, series II, Varian). 2.3 Catalytic activities The catalytic activities of the prototype catalysts were evaluated using multiple micro-flow fixed-bed reactors that emulate the hydrotreating reactions in commercial hydroprocessing guard-bed reactor (Xytel, India Private Ltd.). The catalysts were loaded in five zones and diluted with carborundum (1:1 ratio). The average extrudate diameter was 2.2 mm, and the average length of the extrudates was 4.5 mm. The catalyst presulfiding was performed using the wet method, where gas oil was spiked with carbon disulfide and then pumped into the reactor to sulfide the catalyst. The operating conditions used for the catalytic tests were as follows: LHSV = 1.0 h−1, H2/Oil = 680, temperature = 380−400 °C, and pressure = 120 bar. The selected feed for catalysts assessment was the heavy Mexican Ku crude, which is known for its high metals and asphaltene contents, Table 1 . 2.4 Characterization and textural properties of fresh and spent catalysts 2.4.1 Textural properties The fresh and spent catalysts were characterized by two standard textural analysis methods: mercury porosimetry and physical adsorption of nitrogen. The nitrogen physisorption was measured by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at −196 °C, using Micrometrics volumetric adsorption analyzer (Model ASAP 2020, V4.03). The BET technique has limitations when it comes to macropores measurements. Therefore, mercury (Hg) porosimetry (AutoPore IV9500, V1.09, Micromeritics, USA) was also utilized as it is known to be an extremely useful characterization technique for porous materials, particularly pores that have a diameter between 500 μm and 3.5 nm. This technique delivers a wide range of information such as total pore volume (PV), pore size distribution (PSD), average pore diameter (APD), and the pore area (PA). Nevertheless, mercury porosimetry also has its own limitations when it comes to measuring pore diameter less than 3.5 nm. Therefore, both techniques were utilized in this study as they complement each other in fully characterizing the spectrum of pore types. 2.4.2 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) Thermogravimetric analysis of supports was carried out using a TGA-DSC 1 Mettler Toledo equipment (GmBH, Germany) at the temperature range from 50 to 700 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C/min, under oxygen atmosphere with a flow rate of 25 mL/min. A mass of 12−15 mg of sample was used in 70 μL aluminum crucibles. 2.4.3 SEM mapping The surface morphological structure of toluene-washed spent catalysts was observed by the scanning electron microscope-energy dispersive X-ray (SEM-EDX) analysis using a JEOL JSM-IT300 with oxford instrumentation energy dispersive system. The catalyst extrudates were mounted vertically on an aluminum sample holder and evacuated at high vacuum (10−5 Torr), then images were taken with the secondary electron detector. The conditions of analysis were 20–30 kV. The semiquantitative analysis of elemental composition was studied by SEM-EDS using AZtecEnergy EDS software. The SEM results indicate the agglomeration of the foreign particles that caused catalyst deactivation due to the loss of catalytic sites. 3 Results and discussion Metal impurities in heavy petroleum feedstock are considered one of the main causes for catalyst deactivation in hydrotreatment. Such deactivation normally occurs through two deactivation mechanisms, namely, active site poisoning and pore mouth plugging. The guard-bed HDM catalysts are known for their high metal retention capacity and large pores, and normally utilized to selectively remove the metal impurities from the feedstock. The metal removal in the early stages of hydrotreatment is essential for protecting the downstream HDS and HDN catalysts. In this study, FeMo supported catalysts were designed and engineered by selecting mixtures of support components (i.e., carbon-alumina ratios) and by introducing support pretreatment methodology for pore expansion. The newly designed catalysts are characterized by large pores (i.e., macro-pores), which have been achieved by utilizing both carbon and pore enlarging agent (PEG) in the support and by following a specific calcination methodology. During calcination, both carbon and PEG were burnt out under an optimized temperature, heating rate, and rotating furnace speed. Hence, the support composition and the pretreatment methodology are the basis for the new synthesizing approach to modify the physical properties and the pore size distribution. 3.1 Thermal stability of supported catalysts To determine the thermal stability of supported catalysts, the dried support has been pretreated once with air (i.e., calcination) and once with the inert He gas at 550 °C for 4 h. Both pretreated support samples were decarbonized by TGA at a temperature range of 50−700 °C. The results of the TGA analysis are summarized as solid material loss in Fig. 1 a. The decompositions of PEG and carbon respectively occurred at 350 and 492 °C, as shown in Fig. 1b. The figure also indicates that the decomposition of carbon in the support pretreated with inert gas (i.e., He gas) occurred at a slightly higher temperature (i.e., 507 °C) due to alumina interaction. On the other hand, no significant sign of carbon decomposition (i.e., a flat line for TGA analysis) was observed for the support pretreated with reactive gas (i.e., air), which is mainly due to the fact that most of the carbon in the support was burned in the calcination process. Fig. 1c clearly illustrates that the weight loss in the air pretreated catalyst is around 6%, which primarily represents the small amount of carbon remaining after calcination. In developing these guard-bed HDM catalysts, the optimum activation conditions were carefully studied and established in order to generate the required textural properties, which include the specific surface area (SSA), total pore volume (TPV), average pore diameter (APD), and pore size distribution (PSD). These activation conditions are responsible for burning out the carbon in the support, which eventually leads to the large textures (inter-particle distance) in the support. The macro-pores and interparticle distances are shown in Fig. 1d. The optimum activation conditions are very important parameters in developing these catalysts since inappropriate or severe activation conditions usually reduce the mechanical properties (i.e., crushing and attrition) of the catalysts [15]. As previously indicated in the experimental section, several prototype supports with different amounts of carbon were synthesized in an effort to enhance the textural and mechanical properties of the guard-bed HDM catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the TGA analyses for these prototype supports along with the decomposition derivatives. The observed weight losses in the TGA results mainly corresponds to carbon decomposition in the support. The carbon decomposition at our conditions occurs between 400 and 550 °C. The figure shows that boehmite (uncalcined alumina) has around 20−25 wt.% moisture or water content, which is eliminated below 400 °C. The TGA data also designates the thermal decomposition of other species, where two discrete exotherms are observed at 475 and 500 °C. Significant percentages of losses in these exotherms are primarily due to the extensive oxidation of carbon. The observed weight loss in the first step is nearly 4 %, and it is mainly related to the removal of moisture and organic substances through desorption. On the other hand, the second weight loss happened between 266 and 490 °C and reached its maximum at 380 °C. The amount of weight loss in the second region was around 38.7 wt.%, and it primarily corresponds to the partial oxidation of carbon in the support. The third weight loss occurred at a temperature range of 495 and 546 °C, where the broad exothermic peak had its maximum at 500 °C. The amount of weight loss in the third region was found to be about 53.9 wt.%, and it corresponds to the nearly total oxidation of carbon in the support. The derivative curve peak had shoulders indicate more than one type of material decomposition. Fig. 2b presents the final weight loss for each transition at 200, 475, and 500 °C. The temperature at which the derivative of weight loss starts is chosen as the zero loss point, and the temperature at which the weight derivative returned to the baseline is the endpoint. All individual supports were analyzed, and a plot of the derivative curves were compared for variation in decomposition temperature (Fig. 2b), which mainly depends on the physical interaction of carbon within the alumina matrix. The pure compound has a sharper peak, indicating that the decomposition is governed by a global mechanism with a single weight loss transition, which corresponded to the main weight loss transition (Fig.1b). The three significant derivative peaks in all samples were observed, which correspond to moisture, OH group decomposition in the alumina, and carbon decomposition. 3.2 Textural properties characterization The textural properties of the supported catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption (BET method) and mercury porosimetry. Fig. 3 illustrates the relation between the various textural properties, which include the surface area (SSA), the total pore volume (TPV), and the average pore diameter (APD), using both techniques. Fig. 3a and c illustrate the evaluation of textural properties through nitrogen adsorption-desorption. N2 adsorption allows the precise calculation of micropores with the help of mono and multi-layers’ adsorption, including capillary condensation. On the other hand, the amount of macropores was calculated using the results obtained from the mercury porosimetry (Fig. 3b and d). The observed difference in results between both techniques is due to their own limitations. The BET method is a very powerful technique for measuring micropores (<2 nm) but has a limitation when it comes to macropore measurement (>50 nm). On the contrary, mercury porosimetry is an extremely useful characterization technique for mesopores (2−50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm) but cannot measure micropores. The smallest pore that can be measured in mercury porosimetry is 3.5 nm, which corresponds to the maximum operating pressure of 60,000 psi. Fig. 4 shows an example of pore-size distributions of one of the prototype catalysts (i.e., HDM-6), where physical adsorption of nitrogen and mercury porosimetry are compared. It is obvious that mercury penetrates to the wider pores (>2 nm) while N2 physisorption only determined micro- and some mesopores using BJH algorithm. Therefore, both techniques are considered complementary to each other in this study to fully determine the spectrum of pore types. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms for both fresh and spent catalysts correspond to type IV isotherm, which is a characteristic of mesoporous materials. Although the results shown in Figs. 3 and 4 illustrate a considerable data overlap between both techniques, which prevents viewing the clear trends among the textural properties, the results still strongly suggest the impact of support composition on textural properties of prototype catalysts. The impact of pore diameter in the incremental pore volume of the synthesized HDM catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 5 . These results infer that as the carbon content in support increases, the intrusion pore volume of larger pore array gradually increases, while the pore volume in the smaller pore size gradually decreases; that is, the pore structure is continuously refined. To classify the pore aperture size distribution, differential intrusion d V d D = m L g n m or log differential intrusion d V d log ( D ) = m L g can be calculated, which are different expression forms of different units [24]. The figure indicates that most of the prototype catalysts have a bimodal-type pore structure (i.e., meso- and macropores), but the pore size distribution varies with the carbon content. The pore size distribution trend indicates that the percentage of macropores increases with carbon content in the support. However, the significant increase in the carbon content has completely vanished the mesopores, which resulted in a mono-modal type pores, as shown in catalyst HDM-8. The relatively higher carbon content in HDM-8 has affected not only the pore size distribution but also the pore area and the total pore volume, as shown in Table 2 . The observed deterioration in the textural properties of catalyst HDM-8 was also associated with a decline in its mechanical properties, such as crushing strength and bulk density. The results indicated in Fig. 5 and Table 2 clearly suggest that the carbon content in the supported catalyst has an optimum value, beyond which the textural and the mechanical properties are affected. The detailed textural properties of the six prototype catalysts are reported in Table 2. The observed variations in textural properties are mainly attributed to the different carbon contents since the support pretreatment conditions for pore enlargement are similar. Alumina, which is used as a binder (γ-Al2O3), has transformed from boehmite [Al(OH)3] during calcination at around 550 °C. The loss of surface groups is responsible for creating micro-pores, which contribute to the increase in the specific surface area. The pore distribution in Table 2 clearly indicates that carbon utilization in the alumina support has significantly increased the proportion of meso- and macro-pores in the support. The relatively large pores mainly resulted from the controlled carbon burning during calcination, which was performed in a dynamic rotatory furnace in the presence of air. 3.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The textural properties of prototype FeMo supported catalysts revealed insignificant changes when compared to their corresponding original supports before impregnation. Therefore, the impact of metal impregnation on the textural properties was negligible due to the low concentration of active metals (FeMo) [25]. The catalytic performances of the prototype catalysts were evaluated based on their hydrodemetallization (HDM) and hydrodeasphaltenization (HDAs) activities, using Ku-crude which is known for its high metal and asphaltene contents. The metals and coke depositions are the leading causes of catalysts deactivation in hydrotreatment [5,26,27]. The HDM and HDAs activities for all catalysts were assessed in a continuous flow reactor for an extended time-on-stream (TOS) at different operating temperatures (i.e., 380 °C, 390 °C, and 400 °C). Fig. 6 exemplifies the catalytic performances for all prototype catalysts. HDM-3 catalyst illustrates the highest HDM and HDAs activities, which is mainly attributed to the balance between meso- and macro-pore ratios in its support. Both HDM and HDAs activities are directly correlated to the distribution of macro-pores in the support (i.e., 50 nm–10,000 nm). The observed trends for HDM and HDAs activities have been witnessed at all operating temperatures. The changes in operating temperatures revealed a more evident impact on HDM activity than HDAs, which suggests that HDM reaction is more sensitive to reaction temperature than asphaltene conversion, particularly in the presence of sulfided (anion vacancies) catalyst. Moreover, the extracted and deposited vanadium and nickel may also have contributed to the enhancement in HDM activity by generating additional catalytic sites (autocatalysis) [25,26]. The HDM reaction proceeds through hydrogen dissociative chemisorption that involves multiple bond formation of porphyrin at the catalytic sites (i.e., CUS, coordinative unsaturated sites) and propagates with porphyrin ring opening via hydrogenation. HDM reaction is known to be bi-functional in nature, where the initial step is hydrogenation, and the subsequent is hydrogenolysis, which results in metal sulfide depositions on the catalyst [28,29]. Apart from the catalytic functions, the pore size distribution should be carefully engineered to produce relatively large pore volume to accumulate the heavy nickel and vanadium without encountering the problem of pore mouth plugging. Asphaltene conversion (HDAs), on the other hand, is a more complex reaction as it requires more severe hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis functions. The later function (i.e., hydrogenolysis) is rather limited in the developed prototype catalysts due to the lack of acidic function. However, the lack of acidic function was compensated by generating more macro-pores in the support, which significantly enhanced the diffusion of large hydrocarbon molecules, allowing them to penetrate and reach the inner catalytic sites. The impact of pore diameter in the incremental pore volume of the HDM prototype catalysts was previously illustrated in Fig. 5, where at least two types of pore are observed: mesopores (2−50 nm) and macropores (+50 nm). Fig. 7 a also illustrates the correlation between the pore diameter and the incremental pore area. It is evident from both figures that geometries of pores and its distribution significantly vary between the prototype catalysts, which explain the differences in activities behaviors in hydroprocessing reactions. Catalysts activities gradually decrease with heavy crude hydroprocessing due to coke and metals (or metal sulfide) depositions. The accumulation of these deposits was detrimental and negatively impacted the catalyst's textural properties, as shown in Fig. 7b, which illustrates a significant drop in pore area for spent catalysts. The metal and carbon depositions mainly affected the mesopores, and to a lesser extent the macro-pores. Fig. 8 , on the other hand, illustrates the impact of catalyst deactivation on the incremental pore volume for the different pore sizes. The observed increase in macro-pores percentage (+ 50 nm) in the spent catalysts is mainly attributed to the substantial decrease in meso-pores and the data normalization (i.e., total pores = 100 %). The changes in pore size distribution percentages between fresh and spent catalysts are reported in Table 3 . The previous results clearly indicate that there is an optimal correlation between catalyst textural properties (i.e., pore area, pore volume, and pore diameter) and HDM and HDAs activities, which should be carefully considered when developing a guard-bed catalyst for heavy oil hydroprocessing. The prototype catalysts in this study have a pore diameter range of 20−10000 nm and a total pore volume of 0.3–1.5 ml/g. The key structural changes in the textural properties were measured using Hg intrusion, where the properties of fresh and spent catalysts are compared. Significant changes in the textural properties were observed as catalyst deactivated due to the metal and carbon depositions. The percentages of pore that have a diameter smaller than 100 nm significantly decreased in the spent catalysts due to metal and carbon depositions around the pore-mouth, which eventually plug the relatively smaller pores. This explains why the catalysts with smaller pores tend to deactivate faster than those with larger pores during the HDM and HDAs reactions, where catalysts are typically deactivated through either site coverage and/or pore-mouth plugging. The deactivation by pore-mouth plugging can be evaluated by comparing the textural properties of fresh and spent catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8. The correlation between spent catalysts’ pore volumes (mL/g) and pore size distribution indicates the location of the deposited species. The figure clearly reveals that the amount of meso-pores in all prototype catalysts are considerably affected by the pore-mouth plugging, whereas the macro-pores are relatively less affected by carbon and metal depositions. Catalysts HDM-4 and HDM-5, for example, have large percentages of meso-pores due to the relatively low carbon content in their support composition. The lack of macro-pores in these catalysts enhanced the diffusion limitation for large hydrocarbon molecules, which subsequently affected their HDM and HDAs conversions, as previously illustrated in Fig. 6. The low initial activities and the rapid deactivation observed in catalysts HDM-4 and HDM-5 allowed them to be tested for only 396 and 540 h, respectively. The pore-mouth plugging for meso-pores in HDM-4 and HDM-5 has significantly affected the overall activities of the catalysts as an enormous surface area was neutralized with porosity reduction, which even prevents the smaller molecules to reach the inner active sites. On the contrary, the pores of fresh HDM-8 catalyst are all greater than 1000 nm. The existence of such relatively large macro-pores is mainly due to the high carbon content in the support composition (i.e., 75 wt.%). The results in Fig. 8 suggest that the metal and carbon deposition in this catalyst occurred within the pore walls rather than the pore-mouth, which eventually changed the pore size distribution in the spent catalyst. Fig. 8 also shows a very distinctive bimodal pore for the HDM-3 catalyst, which was significantly changed in the spent catalyst. The meso-pores in the spent catalyst have totally vanished while pores with a diameter greater than 1000 nm have changed considerably. The physical characterization and the activity results in this study clearly indicate that catalysts with small pore diameters (micro and meso-pores) are more vulnerable to rapid deactivation. Thus, the stability of the catalyst in HDM reaction is closely associated with the total pore volume and the mean radius of pores. These textural properties are very crucial for the guard-bed catalysts because they mutually enhance the metal storage capacity and the large molecules diffusion and conversion. Fig. 9 a shows the relationship between support composition and type of pores in the catalysts, while Fig. 9b elucidates the role of these pores on HDM activity. In agreement with the literature [30–34], Fig. 9b experimentally illustrates how the HDM activity improves as the percentage of macro-pores increases in the supported catalysts, and how the increase in micro- and meso-pores percentages negatively impact the HDM conversion rate. Overall, the results illustrated in this section clearly indicate that optimum carbon content in the HDM supported catalyst should be around 50 wt.% (i.e., carbon-alumina weight ratio is 1:1), beyond which obvious deteriorations are observed in HDM and HDAs activities as well as in the textural and mechanical properties. This finding was clearly notable in the performance of catalyst HDM-3, which has a very distinctive bimodal pore structure and illustrated relatively higher HDM and HDAs activities. The coke and metals depositions on the spent catalysts were further analyzed and semi-quantified using the SEM-EDX analysis. Fig. 10 presents the SEM-EDS spectrum and the elemental mapping of a micro-area in spent catalyst S-HDM-3. The analysis reveals the deposition of carbon (i.e., coke) and metals on the spent catalyst, which includes Ni, V, Mo, Fe, S, Al, along with lesser amounts of Si and P. The depositions of coke and metals on the catalyst surface resulted in deactivating catalyst through active site poisoning and pore-mouth plugging. The coke formation, in such a hydrotreatment process, results from the cracking of large hydrocarbon molecules, whereas metal deposition results from selective hydrodemetallization reactions. Nickel and vanadium are naturally the most abundant in petroleum feedstock, and they are frequently associated with the asphaltenes fractions [35], where they exist in porphyrin forms. As previously indicated, metals in hydroprocessing are normally extracted and deposited in the form of metal sulfides. Vanadium extraction is relatively easier than nickel extraction, and therefore it is more frequently deposited near the outer surface of the catalyst. Nickel, on the other hand, is more frequently deposited within the catalyst’s inner surfaces. Fig. 11 illustrates the traces of metals that are deposited on the catalyst surface along with their semiquantitative (kα) analyses. The higher content of vanadium compared to nickel, in Fig. 11, is attributed to its relatively easier extraction and to its higher content in the feedstock (i.e., Ku crude has 476 ppm vanadium and 92 ppm nickel). According to some literature, the deposition of Ni and V, in the form of metal sulfides (i.e., Ni3S2, V3S2, and V3S4), partially promotes the HDM activity by generating autocatalytic sites [24,25]. The deposited vanadium and nickel sulfides were also reported for their crystallite size using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, which grew significantly on the alumina surface even at 60 h of TOS [36]. Ni and V may also have metal-metal interaction with Fe, Ca, and Mg, which enhances the catalyst poisoning through particle growth around the pore-mouth and active catalytic sites. Fig. 11 also illustrates high sulfur content in the spent catalyst. The main source of sulfur in the spent catalyst is metal sulfides. On the other hand, the Na is found in the feedstock in a very small amount (3.3 ppm) in the form of salt, most likely NaCl. The 100 % retention of salt content indicates that guard catalyst plays multifunction (filter and guard) role of catalytic and non-catalytic phenomena to retain deposited species [37]. The coke deposition in spent catalyst, on the other hand, was analyzed by Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectra for prototype catalyst HDM-7 and its spent catalyst S-HDM-7 are compared in Fig. 12 . The distinctive features in Raman spectra between 800−1000 cm−1 are attributed to monomer surface polymolybdate species, which include the bands 815 cm−1 [υδ (Mo = O)], 990 cm−1 (δ(MoO3), and 925 cm−1 (νs(Mo2O7 2−) [38]. The hub that exists in the fresh catalyst spectrum at wavenumber range of 1400−1800 cm−1 primarily represents the small amount of carbon that remains in the support after calcination. Such undecomposed carbon in the fresh catalyst was also observed in TGA results, which was previously reported in Fig. 1c. The spent catalyst, on the other hand, illustrated two sharp bands at wavelength of 1368 cm−1 and 1600 cm-1, which are respectively known as the D and G bands. These sharp bands signify the carbon deposition and the coke formation from the hydrotreating process, which is inhomogeneous in nature. The D band at 1368 cm−1 exemplifies the formation of disordered or amorphous carbon species while the G band at 1600 cm-1represents the deposited carboneous species of ordered graphitic structure. 4 Conclusions The impact of catalyst textural properties on heavy oil conversion has been investigated in this study. The variations in textural properties were achieved by using different compositions of carbon and alumina in the support and by following a certain pretreatment methodology. The utilization of carbon in the FeMo supported catalysts along with their pretreatment resulted in a large pore volume of 0.5–1.2 ml/g and a wide range of large pores (10–10,000 nm). The large pore volume enhanced the metal storage capacity, which consequently improved catalyst stability. The considerable affinity of carbon in support to adsorb metal porphyrins has reduced the metal depositions on the catalytic sites, which significantly contributed to the stability of the catalyst. The wide range of large pores, on the other hand, resulted in a distinctive bimodal pore structure that minimized the diffusion limitation and allowed the large hydrocarbon molecules to penetrate into the inner pores and reach the deep catalytic sites, which significantly boosted the HDM and HDAs conversions. The textural and mechanical properties, along with the HDM and HDAs activities, clearly indicates that the optimum guard-bed catalyst is obtained when the carbon-alumina weight ratio is 1:1. The study also concluded that the HDM activity in supported catalyst is directly related to the concertation of macro-pores, while it is inversely related to the of meso- and micro-pores concentrations. The fresh and spent catalysts characterization assessment clearly designates that the bimodal type of pore structure significantly contributed to the catalyst stability. coredata.dc:description: The hydrodemetallization (HDM) activity and the stability of FeMo supported catalysts have been investigated during the hydroprocessing of heavy crude oil. The prototype FeMo catalysts were developed in this study as guard-bed catalysts. Such type of front catalyst is frequently used in complex hydrotreatment to protect the more vulnerable subsequent catalysts. Various prototype supports were synthesized in this study to produce different textural properties. Such textural properties were generated and optimized by using different support compositions (0−75 wt.% activated carbon in alumina) and following a certain support pretreatment methodology for pore expansion. Both the support composition and the pretreatment methodology have significantly contributed in developing an optimized HDM catalyst with a large pore volume and a distinctive bimodal pore structure. The large pore volume substantially improved the metal retention capacity, while the bimodal pore structure remarkably reduced the diffusion limitation, allowing the large hydrocarbon molecules (i.e., asphaltene) to reach the inner catalytic sites to enhance their conversion rates. The presence of carbon in the catalyst support, even after calcination, considerably reduced coke and metal depositions on pore-mouths and catalytic sites. The textural and the mechanical properties of support indicate that the optimum composition is attained when the carbon-alumina ratio is 1:1 (50/50 wt.%). The role of textual properties on catalyst stability was investigated by comparing fresh and spent catalysts. The characterization of spent catalysts indicates that the bimodal type of pore has stable performance with time-on-stream (TOS).
coredata.dc:title: Guard-bed catalyst: Impact of textural properties on catalyst stability and deactivation rate
